F test for detecting circadian pattern

Source: R/diffCircadian3.R
FTest.Rd

Test the significance of circadian curve fitting using F test.

Usage

FTest(tt, yy, period = 24)

Arguments

tt

Time vector

yy

Expression vector

period

Period of the since curve. Default is 24.

Value

A list of amp, phase, offset, peak, SST, SSE, R2. Formula 1: \(yy = amp \times sin(2\pi/period \times (phase + tt)) + offset\) Formula 2: \(yy = A \times sin(2\pi/period \times tt) + B * cos(2*pi/period * tt) + offset\)

amp

Amplitude based on formula 1

phase

Phase based on formula 1, phase is restricted within (0, period)

offset

Basal level(vertical shift) based on formula 1 or on formula 2

tss

Total sum of square

rss

Residual sum of square, SSE/n is the MLE of the variance sigma2

R2

Pseudo R2 defined as (tss - rss)/tss

Details

sourced from: https://rdrr.io/github/diffCircadian/diffCircadian/ under GPL3 license author: Zhiguang Huo, Haocheng Ding Feb. 24, 2023, 9:07 a.m.; Version 0.0.0 journal article: https://doi.org/10.1093/bib/bbab224 tutorial (for circadian data): http://htmlpreview.github.io/?https://github.com/diffCircadian/diffCircadian/blob/master/vignettes/diffCircadian_tutorial.html

Author

Caleb (Zhiguang Huo)

Examples

set.seed(32608)
n <- 50
Period <- 24
tt <- runif(n,0,Period)
Amp <- 2
Phase <- 6
Offset <- 3
yy <- Amp * sin(2*pi/Period * (tt + Phase)) + Offset + rnorm(n,0,1)
FTest(tt, yy)
#> $amp
#> [1] 1.915422
#> 
#> $phase
#> [1] 6.536394
#> 
#> $offset
#> [1] 3.028329
#> 
#> $rss
#> [1] 27.31912
#> 
#> $tss
#> [1] 125.0438
#> 
#> $R2
#> [1] 0.7815237
#> 
#> $df1
#> [1] 2
#> 
#> $df2
#> [1] 47
#> 
#> $stat
#> [1] 84.06316
#> 
#> $pvalue
#> [1] 2.992272e-16
#>
